I recently decided to check on the balance of payments in 1946-1973 to see if our prosperity was based on making money off of the rest of the world. It was not. The balance of payments for that period flucuated a little around zero.

Note that the period of very high tax rates on the Rich, deficit spending, low inequality and strong unions which produced great prosperity lasted 27 years, way, way beyond any effects from WWII.

And what about post WWI, when we had very low tax rates on the Rich, balanced budgets for 10 years, very high inequality, and weak unions? Do you know what happened in October of 1929?

I dunno--my parents did not suffer from layoffs but I have. And my generation has no union to back us up, or pensions--those 401(k) accounts are a real joke. We may even lose social security if the right winger Koch lapdogs get their way. We've really been hung out to dry.

Finally, a sensible approach to the politics of inequality! Thank you, Professor Khan. You (along with Professor Stiglitz) make me glad to be a Columbia alumnus.

Here are a couple of further thoughts. First, perhaps the American prosperity of the 1950s and 1960s was also related to the fact that the rest of the industrialized world had self-destructed during WWII, and we had virtually no economic competition. The Russian and Chinese dictatorships continued the tradition of our competitors shooting themselves in the foot until about 1990. It was hard on the Russians and Chinese but great for us.

Also, statistical studies like the one by the Santa Fe Institute show that personal income is almost entirely determined by the financial position of one's parents. For instance, aside from low income African Americans, education has no effect. (Don't believe it? Read the paper, which is available on line.) I would also like to see the evidence for the idea that most very rich people 'earned it themselves.' I doubt it.

There is no good reason to hand the already rich huge tax advantages like low rates on unearned income (capital gains) and virtually zero taxes on inheritance ('step us basis') and no tax on stock sales (while sale of the family home involves huge transfer taxes).

Note to all supposed free market advocates:
A perfectly unregulated market does not necessarily constitute a TRULY free market, in my personal estimation, if the prices -- of labor or goods -- are not the highest that purveyors are able to extract from buyers; the max that buyers are freely willing to pay. Another way of saying this is that a market is not REALLY free unless the sellers are free to reject a price they know is less than the buyer is willing to pay.

A perfect example of not TRULY free labor market -- even though totally unregulated -- is right from the beginning of the Industrial Revolution: individual hand weavers earned a fair living bargaining one-to-one with buyers -- replaced by 100 times more productive power loom operators whose families lived on oat cakes because they could not afford wheat bread.

To me the question of humanity or welfare are completely irrelevant in the minimum wage debate -- cannot extract more than buyers are will to pay; but must try to extract that much.

A $15 an hour minimum wage would shift about $560 billion from the 55% who now take 90% of overall income to the 45% of Americans who take only 10% -- or about 4%. I don't foresee the 55% tellling the 45%: Stay home; we don't need your output anymore, over a 4% overall price increase. :-)

I was enraged this fall when, vis a vis the troubled rollout of Obamacare, legislators crowed about Medicare Part D's "success" despite ITS troubled rollout. Perhaps if they were forced to take THEIR Rx coverage under Part D they would opine differently.

I believe the only people for whom Medicare Part D could possibly have succeeded would have been very poor people who previously had no Rx coverage & who were chronically ill & requiring expensive meds on a recurring basis, w/ no unexpected meds prescribed mid-year.

Why Congress didn't just amend Medicare to provide that, after an Rx deductible of a certain amount, drugs would be covered at "x"% or for a " y" copay for generics & a" z" copay for brands is beyond me.

Instead we have the "competitive" nightmare of Part D, where:

1. Part D insurers have different formularies, a drug covered by one may not be covered by another; & a drug covered by both plans may be "Tier 1" under one &" Tier 2" under another.

2. Some Part D insurers don't have complete formularies printed or online.One must ask about a specific drug & heaven help you if you don't know in Dec. what a doc may prescribe for an emergency in July.

3. Under some plans a drug prescribed in quantity of 90 every 60 days costs 10 times as much per fill as one prescribed in quan. of 90 every 30 days.

4. Often one is better skipping insurance & paying retail, but because of penalties for failing to sign up at 65, millions overpay (& insurers gain).

This is an incredibly misinformed post.

NAFTA contains an entire chapter on intellectual property. Article 1709 deals solely with patents.

Taiwan has been a WTO member since 2002, and has implemented the TRIPS agreement. No, they don't have to respect US patents: they have to respect Taiwanese patents. And foreign pharmaceutical firms are sure to patent any product of value in Taiwan, just as they do in France, Russia, or India.

Medical research is not "free of charge for everyone." Indeed, there is an important debate about access to publicly-funded scientific research going on in the US and around the world, since typically such research is published in academic journals which require an expensive subscription, despite being produced using taxpayer money.

One thing is accurate: public funding of research does constitute a subsidy to the pharmaceutical industry, and our high drug prices in the U.S. (and to a far lesser extent, Europe) do act as a subsidy for the rest of the world.

The U.S. is anything but a "big loser" on IP. We are probably the top exporter of intellectual property in the strict sense, as well as "IP-intensive" products in the entire world.

If you mean that we are a "loser" in the sense that we cannot apply our domestic law to foreign countries, or force them to interpret TRIPS in a manner than suits us, perhaps you are right.

No one expects the US to eliminate patent protection. As a member of the WTO and the TRIPS agreement, as well as numerous other international agreements and treaties, we cannot legally do so.

However, nothing stops us from setting up an alternative incentive mechanism, such as prizes, to the patent system. There is a lot of academic research showing how such an alternative system can be especially useful for neglected diseases. See, e.g., Aidan Hollis, "The Health Impact Fund: A Useful Supplement to the Patent System?", Public Health Ethics, Vol. 1, Iss. 2, http://phe.oxfordjournals.org/content/1/2/124.short (of course it is paywalled, so you will need an institutional subscription, but that is another debate entirely).

The fact that the effect was most pronounced among higher educated people might seem to weigh against this explanation (after all, you'd expect them to have fewer worries about money and more modern attitudes about gender). But then again, these people might be the most inclined to "save up" after having a daughter, planning ahead for when she's in her mid-twenties, dating "Nate," and trying to sell a screenplay about her life in Brooklyn.
Patriarchy is a poisonous method of exerting oppression over for women and so is religion.

I lived in a highly educated, affluent, predominantly republican suburb for a few years when my daughter was young.  I was shocked at how retro and conservative the parents were in terms of raising their daughters --it was 2001 yet in many ways it felt as if it were 1950.   Girls were expected to excel--excel-- academically, socially and morally. There was a huge amount of pressure and competition among parents to have what were viewed as 'good girls' and that was very narrowly defined.  Obedient, slender (NEVER overweight, never), rule-followers.   When my daughter was about mid-way through kindergarten, I realized that her teacher was really angry with her because my daughter hadn't mastered the skill of raising her hand to ask permission to speak.  The teacher was used to a classroom of girls competing to be the best good girl, and was clearly upset by my daughter's inability to stifle.  I realized pretty quickly that this pressure to develop the façade of a perfect, self-contained, virginal princess was only going to increase, and we moved.  If it's true that parents become more conservative when they have daughters, it may not be for the best reasons, particularly if the trend is most noticeable among educated, affluent parents as the study suggests.  It may be that they become more restrictive and controlling and put a lot of pressure on their daughters to be good girls in all the old familiar, patriarchal ways.
But coddle them is what  the US government and it's Owners, do.
